title: Thirupukazh (The Glory of the Divine)
author: Arunagirinathar
introduction: Thirupukazh, meaning 'Praise of the Lord,' is a masterpiece of devotional poetry in Tamil, consisting of hymns dedicated to Lord Murugan (Kartikeya). Composed by the saint-poet Arunagirinathar in the 15th century, the verses are renowned for their rhythmic complexity (Chandam) and profound spiritual content, focusing on the pursuit of spiritual liberation and the glory of Murugan's six abodes (Arupadaiveedu) and other sacred Sthalas (temples). The surviving collection contains approximately 1,307 songs.

chapters.name: Tirupparankundram (Verses 1-56)
chapters.summary: This chapter is dedicated entirely to the songs composed by Arunagirinathar at the Tirupparankundram temple, glorifying Lord Murugan's victory over the Asuras and his compassionate nature as a savior.

verses.original: कैकैयु मुटऱ् कैयतुण्टु कऩियेप्पऴ मुरुक्का मुऩैक्
verses.transliteration: Kaikeiyum uṭaṟ kaiyatuṇṭu kaṉiyeppaḻ murukkā muṉaik

translations.english: O Ganesha (the one with the elephant trunk and large body), who holds a fruit in your hand! You bestow the sweet fruit of grace upon those who approach you.
O Lord (Murugan), who is the son of Shiva! The celestial beings (Devas) and enlightened ones sing good songs in your praise.
You are the Pearl (Muttā), who came down to this world as a doctor, performing extraordinary deeds.
O Lord who stands as a rarity and who possesses great glory!

verses.original: ऊऩाटि नीयऩ्ऱु ōर् क्ōट्टु मुत्तु नल्लिऩ
verses.transliteration: Ūṉāṭi nīyaṉṟu ōr kōṭṭu muttu nalliṉa

translations.english: You who danced in the flesh (human form), once gave the pearl (of wisdom) to the one who asked.
O Lord who possesses the bow that is difficult to attain and who wields the bow with strength!
There is no one (among the skilled) who can defeat you, the foremost mighty one, at any time.
To those who think of you daily, you gladly bestow the things they desire (spiritual realization), though it is difficult to attain.
Having taken a physical form and not letting go of the habits ingrained since the beginning, and as the eyes close (in death), will I be able to utter your sacred name, Muruga?
You, who reside with the golden goddess (Deivanai/Devasena) and wear ornaments that shine amidst the music of devotion, please grant me the boon of your grace.
